metadata.sermon_title: The Father Who Does Not Devour
metadata.notes: Preached in 1994, focusing on the character of God vs. human projections of parental wrath.

freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.score_explanation: 10 = Completely free from coercive judgments. 0 = Very dominant Critical Parent.
freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.analysis: The preacher actively deconstructs the Critical Parent archetype (the 'devouring Neptune') rather than inhabiting it. He identifies the CP as a projection of human trauma rather than a divine reality.
quotes: We do not believe in angry gods who demand human sacrifice.
The fearsome ogre turned out to be the loving father.

healthy_care_NP.score_explanation: 10 = Healthy, non-smothering care. 0 = Absent or smothering.
healthy_care_NP.analysis: The Nurturing Parent is present through the image of the 'Space of Grace.' It is supportive because it emphasizes safety as a prerequisite for change, though it risks slight dependency by framing God as the ultimate 'Good Father' to fix the 'Bad Father' trauma.
quotes: When the son knew he was safe from the devouring mouth, he was able to receive forgiveness.

adult.analysis: The preacher uses psychological observation and cultural analysis (Opera, Film, Psychology) to engage the listener's intellect. He invites the listener to observe their own internal 'projections' objectively.
quotes: We are moved by the drama... because of the universal themes.
Every parish priest will tell you that there are countless numbers of big, strong, grown men... terrorized in their inner selves.

freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.score_explanation: 10 = Free from fear/compliance. 0 = Strong Adapted Child (fear culture).
freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.analysis: The sermon explicitly attempts to liberate the listener from the Adapted Child position (fear of not 'measuring up'). However, the mention of the General Confession ('no health in us') briefly touches the AC's guilt.
quotes: The struggle to believe that one is good enough to pass muster before some dreadful Judge.

free_child_FC.analysis: Authentic relief and a sense of 'Amazing Grace' provide a Free Child payoff, though the tone remains somewhat somber and academic.
quotes: Amazing grace! The fearsome ogre turned out to be the loving father.

transaction_analysis.analysis: The preacher speaks as an observer of human nature to the listener's own observing self, then transitions to a Nurturing Parent offering comfort to the listener's inner Child.
transaction_analysis.ulterior_motives: Minimal. The preacher is transparent about his own failures as a father, which prevents a 'holier-than-thou' ulterior transaction.
transaction_analysis.risk_explanation: The only minor risk is the 'Bait' of the scary Neptune imagery, but it is used for illustration rather than manipulation.

games_analysis.absence_of_games_analysis: The preacher avoids NIGYSOB by explicitly rejecting the 'angry God' narrative. He avoids ITHY by admitting his own faults ('I am sorry to say that my own children have sometimes experienced me this way'), thus refusing the role of the perfect Rescuer.

preacher_roles.rescuer: Low; he points to God as the one who enters the 'water with snakes' rather than claiming to save the congregation himself.
preacher_roles.persecutor: Absent; he actively argues against the Persecutor image of God.
preacher_roles.victim: Low; he briefly identifies with the struggle of being a flawed father.

drama_triangle_analysis.congregation_position: The congregation is acknowledged as being in the 'Victim' position (of their own fears/trauma), but they are invited to step out of it.
drama_triangle_analysis.escape_possibilities: Yes, through the 'Space of Grace' which promotes autonomy from the internal 'Ogre'.

conclusion_and_recommendation.summary: This sermon is psychologically sophisticated and exceptionally healthy. It uses TA-adjacent concepts (projections of parental figures) to dismantle religious manipulation. By identifying the 'Critical Parent' as a human projection rather than a divine attribute, the preacher facilitates a move from a fear-based Adapted Child response to an Adult/Free Child state of grace.
strengths: Vulnerability: The preacher admits his own failures, breaking the 'Perfect Parent' illusion.
Deconstruction of Fear: Effectively separates the 'God of the Bible' from the 'God of Trauma'.
areas_for_improvement: The use of the Franklin Graham story, while effective in 1994, carries heavy baggage today (as noted in the footnote), which might trigger a 'Crossed Transaction' for modern listeners.
conclusion_and_recommendation.advice_for_game_free_communication: Continue using 'I' statements regarding failure. Ensure that the 'Adult' processing of the text remains the primary bridge before moving into the 'Nurturing Parent' comfort.
